metadata.title: The Cotton Harvester in Retrospect: Labor Displacement or Replacement?

dependent_variables.displaced: 79 percent of the reduction in hand picking of cotton was due to increased nonfarm wages; 21 percent was attributed to the decreased cost of machine harvesting.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The U.S. farm labor force declined by about two-thirds from 1930 to 1980, and the machinery-labor ratio increased nearly tenfold.

outcomes.main_findings: The pull effect of higher nonfarm wages was almost four times stronger than the push effect of mechanization in reducing farm labor employment in cotton harvesting.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that labor was primarily pulled out of agriculture by higher wages in nonfarm occupations rather than being displaced by mechanical cotton harvesters.
